questions.text: Which of these drugs is most frequently used prior to administration of  anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Glycopyrrolate is the drug used most frequently prior to anesthesia. 

 
Glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic medication and is used to decrease stomach, mouth, and throat secretions prior to surgery.

  • Glycopyrrolate is a synthetic quaternary ammonium derivative of atropine. Due to its quaternary structure, which is charged in nature, it cannot cross the blood brain barrier and hence its anticholinergic effects are confined to the periphery. Hence, it is used more frequently compared to other anti-cholinergics. 
  • The activity of glycopyrrolate also lasts longer than that of atropine.
  • Often, anesthetic agents are combined with premedication of a barbiturate or benzodiazepine and an antisialagogue (e.g., glycopyrrolate) to facilitate management. The premedications reduce the dose requirement for anesthetic agent, and the antisialagogue reduces the sometimes troublesome salivation and respiratory secretions. This helps in prevention of aspiration.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 666.

questions.text: A woman  with meningioma with Perilesional edema was posted for surgery. The error made by a junior resident when writing pre-op notes is:
questions.solution:
• Perilesional edema or vasogenic edema is a type of swelling that can occur in the brain after a cerebral infarct, or stroke or surrounding a tumour. It occurs when the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is damaged and the brain is no longer able to maintain adequate homeostatic control of the interstitial pressure.
  • Steroids are commonly used to reduce the edema, lower the intracranial pressure and improve symptoms. Therefore, it is important to continue taking the steroids and make sure to take the morning dose.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 664, 665.

questions.text: What makes soda lime so effective at absorbing CO2 in closed-loop anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Calcium hydroxide, also known as slaked lime, is the most important constituent of soda lime in a closed circuit system designed for the reabsorption of carbon dioxide (CO2).
  • This is because calcium hydroxide reacts with the CO2 to form calcium carbonate, which is insoluble and can be removed from the system, thus preventing the accumulation of CO2.
  • Additionally, the calcium hydroxide also helps to raise the pH of the system, ensuring that hydroxide ion concentration remains high, which helps to prevent CO2 from being released.
  • As soda lime is widely used in closed circuit oxygen applications, its proper utilization requires calcium hydroxide as the main component.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 608, 609.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of anaphylaxis in the immediate perioperative period?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of perioperative anaphylaxis are Antibiotics and Muscle relaxants followed by opioids and intravenous anesthesia.
  •  Induction agents causing anaphylaxis is rare.
  • In the older French study (2004), the most common causes were neuromuscular blocking agents (58%), latex (20%), and antibiotics (13%). Conversely, in the more recent United Kingdom study (2016), the most common precipitating agents were antibiotics (53%), neuromuscular blocking agents (33%), and chlorhexidine (9%). 
  • In this question, since Antibiotics is not in option so preferred answer should be Muscle relaxants.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 980.

questions.text: Which nerve is commonly used for assessing the degree of neuromuscular block during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Ulnar Nerve.
 
  • The ulnar nerve is commonly used for assessing the degree of neuromuscular block during anesthesia.
  • The mechanosensor with electrodes is placed over the region of the ulnar nerve. This assesses the contraction of the adductor pollicis muscle to monitor neuromuscular activity.
  • The most commonly assessed nerve-muscle unit is the ulnar nerve-adductor pollicis muscle. 
  • This is because it is easily accessible, has the lowest risk of direct muscle stimulation, and the response can be evaluated visually, by tactile methods, or by objective methods.


Nerve-muscle units that can be assessed:





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1355.

questions.text: All of the following are indications of anticholinergics as a premedication except ?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sedation and amnesia.
 
  • Anticholinergics, such as glycopyrrolate or atropine, are commonly used as premedication to provide certain beneficial effects during anesthesia.
  • Indications for anticholinergics include drying of airway secretions, prevention of bradycardia, and prevention of Gastric aspiration.
  • Some anticholinergics drugs like Scopolamine have mild sedative and amnestic effects, but most anticholinergics do not typically cause sedation or amnesia as they don't cross BBB. 


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 409, 664, 849, 850.

questions.text: A patient is now taking regular drugs for concomitant medical conditions. Which of the following medications can be safely discontinued with a low risk of negative consequences prior to abdominal surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. ACE Inhibitors/ACE Receptors Blockers
 
  • All long-term antihypertensive treatment should be continued up to the day of surgery, with the possible exception of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).
  • Administration of these medications within 24 hours before surgery is consistently associated with increased risks of intraoperative hypotension, and possibly associated with elevated risks of postoperative myocardial injury. Accordingly, it is reasonable to withhold these medications for 24 hours before surgery.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 929.

choices.text: Increased nicotine level may increase sympathetic tone
Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels may shift oxyhemoglobin curve to Right
Reduced pulmonary capacity may result from poor ciliary function and reduced surfactant

questions.text: All of the following statements about the effects of smoking in chronic smokers scheduled for elective surgery are true, except:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels may shift oxyhemoglobin curve to Right
 
  • Increased carboxyhemoglobin levels do not shift the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the right. Instead, they cause leftward shift, reducing the oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin and impairing tissue oxygenation.
  • Smoking should be completely stopped in 6 weeks before surgery because complete recovery of cilia activity takes place in 6 weeks.
  • Smoking when stopped 12 hours before helps decrease nicotine (helps improve cardiac activity) and decreases carbon monoxide (decreases carboxyhemoglobin levels, shifting oxygen dissociation curve to the right and thereby improve O2 delivery to the tissues. 




Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 953, 954.

questions.text: In surgical patients Fifth vital sign commonly elicited by anaesthesiologists is-
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Pain.
 
  • The four traditional vital signs are heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and temperature.
  • Anesthesiologists also consider pain as the fifth vital sign during the perioperative period.
  • Assessing and managing pain is crucial to ensure patient comfort and optimize the overall surgical experience.
  • Anesthesiologists use various techniques and medications to provide adequate pain relief during and after surgery, minimizing the patient's discomfort and facilitating the recovery process. 
  • Moreover, Pain is an important parameter along with vital signs included in PADSS, or postanesthesia discharge scoring system, for assessment of discharge in post-surgical patients from PACU.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2606, 2607.

questions.solution:

As placenta percreta can be adherent to the bladder wall, making bladder injury possible.

questions.text: In asterixis, which of the following would commonly be seen?
questions.solution:
• Asterixis (“flapping tremor”) is a negative myoclonus characterized by sudden loss of muscle tone, often observed when the patient extends the wrists and spreads fingers.

  • Common causes:

    • Hepatic encephalopathy

    • Uremic encephalopathy

    • Hypercapnia (hypercarbia) → seen in respiratory failure

  • Other options:

    • Anxiety neurosis: May cause tremor but not asterixis

    • Thyrotoxicosis: Causes fine tremor, not flapping tremor

    • Hypoxia: Can cause neurological symptoms, but asterixis is not typical

questions.text: Which of the following is a reversal agent for non depolarising muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Answer: Both Sugammadex (Option 1) and Neostigmine (Option 4) are reversal agents for non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. However, Sugammadex is more specific for aminosteroid muscle relaxants.

Explanation:

Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (e.g., Rocuronium, Vecuronium, Atracurium) work by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis. Their reversal is achieved by increasing acetylcholine levels or directly binding the relaxant.

  1. Sugammadex (Option 1) – Most effective and selective

    • Specifically binds to aminosteroid non-depolarizing muscle relaxants (Rocuronium, Vecuronium), rapidly reversing their effect.
    • Acts via encapsulation, preventing the drug from blocking acetylcholine receptors.
    • Fast and effective, with fewer side effects compared to cholinesterase inhibitors.

  2. Neostigmine (Option 4) – Indirect reversal agent

    • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor → Increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, outcompeting the muscle relaxant.
    • Used for both aminosteroid (Rocuronium, Vecuronium) and benzylisoquinolinium (Atracurium, Cisatracurium) relaxants.
    • Administered with Glycopyrrolate (Option 2) to counteract muscarinic side effects (bradycardia, secretions).
To choose between two Suggamadex is an better answer

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 851.

questions.text: WHich of the following is an inhalational anesthetic agent used in children?
questions.solution:
• Sevoflurane is inhalational anesthetic that is used in children.
  • It is Sweet smelling and causes rapid increase in alveolar concentration on inhalation.
  • It has low Solubility in blood hence fastening post Op recovery from anesthesia.

questions.text: A patient who is under general anaesthesia shows the following finding on the ET CO2 monitor. Which condition can lead to this characteristic waveform on capnography?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform depicts bronchospasm.

Shark fin appearance - Prolonged phase Il, increased a angle, and steeper phase II| suggest bronchospasm or airway obstruction.



Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 1311 .

questions.text: Which of the following drug does not act through GABA-A receptors.
questions.solution:
Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases
And is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts or as Perioperative analgesia.
Propofol facilitates the inhibitory neurotransmission by action on
GABA-A receptors. Propofol is formulated as a lipid emulsion and appears as a milky white liquid. It has antiemetic properties which help reduce post-operative nausea and vomiting.
Midazolam is a benzodiazepine that facilitates GABA-A receptors' action by increasing the frequency of opening of GABA-mediated chloride channels. It is used in treating seizures and is used in daycare surgeries.
Thiopentone sodium belongs to the barbiturate group which acts on the GABA-A receptors.
They potentiate the action of GABA in increasing the duration of openings of chloride-specific ion channels.
Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 6th edition • Page no: 183, 386

questions.text: According to ASA grading, what grade is given to a normal individual?
questions.solution:
A normal healthy individual is given grade one according to the ASA grade. ASA Grade,Definition
ASA I,A normal healthy patient. No organic, physiological, biochemical, or psychiatric disturbances.
ASA II,A patient with mild systemic disease. No significant functional limitations.
ASA III,A patient with severe systemic disease. Functional limitations are present but not incapacitating.
ASA IV,A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
ASA V,A moribund patient not expected to survive without the operation.
ASA VI,A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes. Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page 987

questions.text: Identify which class of mallampatti classification does the following image fall under
questions.solution:
Modified Mallampati classification:
• Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis.
• Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
• Class Il: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.
• Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible.
• Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all. Only hard palate visible.
Ref: Anesthesiology Clinics
Volume 33, Issue 2, June 2015, Pages 279-290

questions.text: Which anaesthetic scoring system Is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The Mallampatti rating is a grading system used to determine the difficulty of laryngeal intubation.

Other choices
1. Laryngoscopic views are graded from | (the best view) to IV (the most difficult view) on the Cormack and Lehane grading scale.

2. The purpose of the ASA physical status categorization is to evaluate the comparative risk of surgical anesthesia and sedation. It is ranked from I to VI, where I denotes a healthy individual and VI denotes a patient who is brain dead.

3. The grading of palatine tonsil hypertrophy is called the Brodsky classification.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia 8th edition page no 1092

questions.text: The mask given below works on which of the following principles?
questions.solution:
The Venturi mask is an important device used in oxygen therapy, particularly beneficial for patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Here's a comprehensive overview:

Mechanism of Action

  • Bernoulli Principle: The Venturi mask operates based on the Bernoulli principle, which states:

    As the velocity of a fluid (or gas) increases, the pressure within that fluid decreases.High-Velocity Jet: The mask contains a narrow constriction through which oxygen flows at high speed. This creates a low-pressure area that entrains (draws in) room air through side ports.

  • The resulting mixture of oxygen and room air allows the mask to deliver a precise and consistent FiO₂ (fraction of inspired oxygen).
     

  • The Venturi mask functions based on the Bernoulli principle and Venturi effect.

  • It entrains room air into high-flow oxygen, creating a precisely controlled FiO₂.

  • Especially valuable in managing COPD patients, where precise oxygen therapy is essential to avoid respiratory depression.


Reference:Morgan and Mikhail Clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition page no 1284-1285

questions.text: During the pre anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows
questions.solution:
Mallampati classification is a pre-anesthetic assessment tool used to predict the ease of intubation by visualizing oropharyngeal structures with the patient sitting upright, mouth wide open, and tongue protruded without phonation.

Classes Defined:

Class Structures Visible
Class I Soft palate, fauces, uvula, and pillars
Class II Soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula
Class III Soft palate and base of the uvula
Class IV Only the hard palate is visible
 

"Soft palate, uvula base, and hard palate are visible"

→ This matches Class III, where the soft palate and base of uvula are seen, but not the full uvula or fauces/pillars.

Note:

  • Class III & IV: Predict difficult intubation.

  • Class I & II: Usually indicate easier airway access.



Reference:Millers anesthesia 8th edition page no 1652

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred breathing circuit for spontaneous ventilation in a 20-year-old patient with spontaneous breathing who is undergoing incision and drainage under general anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Mapleson A
 
  • Mapleson A circuit, also known as the "Magill circuit," is the preferred choice for spontaneous ventilation.
  • It allows the patient to breathe spontaneously during the procedure, providing better control over ventilation and maintaining adequate oxygenation.
  • It has a spring-loaded pop-off valve near the facemask. Gas enters the circuit opposite the side of the patient. It is best for allowing spontaneous breathing but worst for controlled ventilation. 
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is A > DFE > CB.
The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A.
   



Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 611-613.

questions.text: Select the option that cannot be used for improving oxygenation in ARDS using a ventilator
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: High-frequency ventilation.
 
  • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation is not typically used as a primary mode of ventilation for ARDS.
  • In ARDS, the mainstay of ventilatory management is Low tidal volume ventilation @ 6-8 ml/kg with high PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure).
  • Low tidal volume ventilation helps reduce lung injury and improve oxygenation by minimizing lung stretch and maintaining alveolar recruitment. High PEEP prevents lung from collapsing. 
  • High-frequency oscillatory ventilation, although used in certain specific cases, is not the standard approach for managing ARDS.
  • Apart from these, prone position, early neuromuscular blockade (to prevent the patient from fighting the ventilator), and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) have also been shown to improve mortality in patients with ARDS. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2227-2229

questions.text: Which of the following devices is related with the names Brechner and Bethune?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: End tidal capnography.
 
  • End tidal capnography is a monitoring technique used to measure the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO2) at the end of expiration.
  • It provides continuous and real-time information about the patient's ventilation and can help detect changes in the airway or breathing patterns.
  • Brechner and Bethune are known for their contributions to the development and advancement of end tidal capnography as a monitoring tool in anesthesia.
  • End tidal capnography is widely used to ensure proper ventilation, assess the effectiveness of CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation), and monitor patients under general anesthesia.


Reference: Pattison WJ. End-Tidal Carbon Dioxide Levels in the Early Detection of Air Embolism. Anaesthesia and Intensive Care. 1975;3(1):58-59. doi:10.1177/0310057X7500300111

questions.text: The image of a pro-seal-type LMA is given below. Above what site is the A-marked area of the airway positioned?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Above esophagus
 
  • The internal gastric tube (drainage tube), which is kept immediately above the esophageal aperture to aspirate GI fluids, is indicated by the arrow.
  • A reusable supraglottic airway device called the LMA ProSealTM includes a gastric drainage tube that is positioned lateral to the main airway tube and terminates at the tip of the mask.
  • By separating the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts, the gastric drainage tube allows regurgitated fluid to flow up the drain tube and bypass the glottis, shielding the airway from contamination in the event of passive regurgitation.



​​​​Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1389-1392.

questions.text: A resident was operating on a patient when she abruptly observed the following plot on the capnograph monitor. What treatment course should be given to the patient immediately?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Increase muscle relaxant
 
  • The capnograph shown here shows " Curare clefts”. It is seen during spontaneous ventilation & cleft is seen in last third of plateau.
  • Clefts during phase III indicating spontaneous breathing efforts during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • The cleft is caused by lack of synchronous action between the intercostal muscles and diaphragm - most commonly caused by inadequate muscle relaxant  and sedation causing patient to take spontaneous breaths.
  • As the muscle relaxant is given the curve become normal in shape and plateau is normal.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1311.

questions.solution:
The color of a medical oxygen cylinder is a black body, along with a white shoulder.

questions.text: Core temperature measurements usually are not taken from which site during general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
• The oesophagus is the most frequently used site in anaesthetic practise for temperature monitoring, despite the fact that pulmonary artery is the gold standard location for core temperature measurement.
  • The most accurate site to obtain core body temperature is the Hypothalamus. It is located in the base of the brain and acts as the body's thermostat.
  • Tympanic membrane can also be used to monitor core body temperature
  • Core temperature are usually not taken from Rectum due to its variation by external factors.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2342, 2343.

questions.text: Which of the following delivers oxygen at its maximum concentration?
questions.solution:
Among the given options Face mask with reservoir delivers close to 90% oxygen concentration.





​​​​​​Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2595.

questions.text: How long should the patient be pre-oxygenated before being intubated?
questions.solution:
• The recommended duration of preoxygenation before intubation is 3 minutes of deep breathing.
  • The process involves tidal volume ventilation through the face mask for 3 minutes, which allows the exchange of 95% of the gas in the lungs.
  • Transnasal humidified rapid-insufflation ventilatory exchange (THRIVE) at 60 L/min for 3 minutes has been demonstrated to be as effective as tidal volume preoxygenation by face mask.
  • Between the induction of anesthesia and achieving airway security, hypoxemia is possible and is more likely to happen if airway control is challenging.
  • Preoxygenation, also known as denitrogenation, is a technique that can be used to enhance these stores. It involves having the patient breathe 100% oxygen through a tight-fitting facemask prior to the onset of anesthesia. This process provides an increased length of time before hemoglobin desaturation occurs in an apneic patient, known as Apnea time
  • This lengthened apnea time provides an improved margin of safety while the anesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation

Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1380.

questions.text: For how much time should tracheal secretions be suctioned?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 10–15 seconds 
​​​​​​​
  • Tracheal secretions should only be suctioned for 10 to 15 seconds at most.
  • The patient should be preoxygenated for at least a minute with 100% oxygen, and the total suction time should not exceed 10-15 seconds for each attempt.
  • Prolonged suctioning can lead to hypoxia and trauma to the tracheal mucosa.


Reference: 
Pasrija D, Hall CA. Airway Suctioning. [Updated 2023 Feb 15]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557386/

choices.text: Assess the patient, give bag and mask ventilation and look for spontaneous breathing
Start bag and mask ventilation and reintubate

questions.text: A patient who had been on a ventilator for a few days rips out the endotracheal tube all of a sudden. What comes next in management?
questions.solution:
• In self-extubation, assess the patient, give bag and mask ventilation and look for spontaneous breathing.
  • Self-extubation is the deliberate removal of the endotracheal tube by the patient (Most common  form of unplanned extubation, usually occurs at night).
  • Accidental extubation is usually the result of staff improperly manipulating the tube while providing patient care or a non-intentional patient activity, such as coughing (mostly occur in the morning).

Reference: Handbook of Critical and Intensive Care Medicine by Joseph Varon, 4th edition, page no 61-63, 579.
Saeed F, Lasrado S. Extubation. [Updated 2023 Feb 9]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539804/

questions.text: The following is not a sign of respiratory insufficiency:
questions.solution:
All of the following are signs of Respiratory difficulty:
  1. Hypoxia
  2. Inspiratory Stridor
  3. Inability to speak.
 

Cases of Respiratory insufficiency must be tackled as an emergency situation, emergency airway access should be performed for relief.

questions.text: An accident occurred to a construction worker, who then went to the trauma centre after a large concrete block fell on his face. He had significant laryngeal and maxillofacial injuries, it was discovered. He was unable to open his mouth, and upon investigation, it was discovered that both his oropharynx and nasopharynx had obstructions and many fractures. The following action was taken for him in order to keep a patent airway. Which of the following choices accurately defines the procedure?
questions.solution:
• In the given image Cricothyroidotomy is being performed.
  • A cricothyrotomy (also known as a cricothyroidotomy) is an incision made through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to create a patent airway in certain life-threatening circumstances, such as when a foreign body is blocking the airway, when angioedema is present, or when there has been significant facial trauma.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1406-1408.

questions.text: A cholecystectomy under general anaesthesia was arranged for a 40-year-old habitual smoker. He had anaesthetic induction with propofol and vecuronium, and isoflurane was administered to maintain the anaesthesia. The following capnograph plot was seen during the surgery. What might be the reason?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2: Entry into the right-sided bronchus
 
  • The capnograph plot shows a sudden drop in the end-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) level, indicating a change in the ventilation pattern.
  • Entry into the right-sided bronchus during intubation can lead to selective intubation of the right lung, resulting in ventilation of only one lung.
  • This causes a decrease in the exhaled CO2 levels and a characteristic capnograph pattern.
  • The correct placement of the endotracheal tube should be confirmed by auscultation, chest rise, and bilateral breath sounds to ensure proper ventilation.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1397, 1398.
Gandhi, S K et al. “Capnography for detection of endobronchial migration of an endotracheal tube.” Journal of clinical monitoring vol. 7,1 (1991): 35-8. doi:10.1007/BF01617896

The laryngoscope is held in the left hand and introduced from the right side of the patient

questions.text:
At concentrations above MAC, anesthetics cause a shift of EEG wave from?
1. \(\alpha\) to \(\beta\) waves
2.  \(\theta\) to \(\delta\) waves
3. \(\delta\) to \(\theta\) waves
4. \(\theta\) to \(\alpha\) waves
questions.solution:
As the dose increases, the EEG transitions from theta to delta with decreased amplitude, burst suppression and eventually an isoelectric EEG.


Reference: Beekoo, Deepti et al. “Analyzing Electroencephalography (EEG) Waves Provides a Reliable Tool to Assess the Depth of Sevoflurane Anesthesia in Pediatric Patients.” Medical science monitor : international medical journal of experimental and clinical research vol. 25 4035-4040. 30 May. 2019, doi:10.12659/MSM.915640

questions.text: Induction of anesthesia with an inhaled agent occurs more faster with?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Combined with nitrous oxide
 
  • lnduction of inhalational agent is faster, if it is combined with nitrous oxide.
  • The second gas effect usually refers to nitrous oxide combined with an inhalation agent.
  • Since nitrous oxide is not soluble in blood, it is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli, which causes the concentration of the other inhalational anesthetic to suddenly rise, hastening the induction process.
  • An inhalation anesthetic's rate of induction and recovery is primarily determined by the blood gas partition coefficient; lower the blood gas partition coefficient, the faster the induction and recovery.
  • Higher the functional residual capacity, greater is the time required for the anesthetic mixture to replace the normal lung gases.
  • Right-to-Left intracardiac shunt prolongs induction because the systemic arterial blood anesthetic partial pressure rises at a slower rate.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 518-520.

choices.text: Inducing agent and neuromuscular relaxant are administered subsequently
The patient is pre-oxygenated for 3 minutes before the procedure
Cricoid pressure has to be applied till the endotracheal tube has been secured with a cuff
Induction should be done with thiopentone sodium and succinylcholine for muscle relaxation

questions.text: Which of these is not true about rapid sequence induction done in a cardiac patient in emergency?
questions.solution:
• The given patient has a cardiac condition and hence Thiopentone induction is contraindicated in cardiac condition and hence cannot be used
  • Etomidate is the preferred induction agent in such a patient with history of cardiac disease
  • Etomidate is the most cardiostable inducing agent
Rapid Sequence Intubation done in cases of- 
Increased Gastric regurgitation chances- 
1. Pregnancy
2. Full stomach
3. Obstruction  ​​​​​​​

The following conditions should be considered a contraindication for the use of IV barbiturates(Thiopentone):
  1. when there is respiratory obstruction or an inadequate airway, thiopental may worsen respiratory depression
  2. severe cardiovascular instability or shock contraindicate its use
  3. status asthmaticus is a condition in which airway control and ventilation may be worsened further by thiopental
  4. porphyria may be precipitated or acute attacks may be accentuated by the administration of thiopental
  5. without proper induction equipment (IV instrumentation) and airway equipment (means of artificial ventilation), thiopental should not be administered.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 653, 668, 1382, 1383.

questions.text: What is correct sequence of age and MAC?

Correct option: 2. Infants>Neonates>Adults
 
  • MAC, the minimum alveolar concentration at 1 atmosphere that prevents movement in 50% of patients exposed to a surgical incision.
  • It decreases with age after 1 year.
  • It is lesser in neonates followed by increase upto 1 year of age and then gradual decline to values lesser then those in neonates.
  • Infants have a higher MAC than that of older children or adults.

questions.text: Modified Mallampati grading is used to evaluate:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Difficult intubation
 
  • Modified Mallampati grading is a classification system used to predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation based on the visualization of the oral cavity and the extent to which the base of the tongue obstructs the view of the larynx.
  • It assesses the structures within the oral cavity, including the soft palate, uvula, fauces, and visibility of the tonsillar pillars.
  • A higher Mallampati grade indicates a more difficult intubation, with Grade 1 being the easiest and Grade 4 being the most challenging.

choices.text: Assertion and reason is true, reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason is true, reason is not explanation for assertion
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: In intubation, extensions of neck and flexion of head is favourable. 
Reason: Jaw thrust removes tongue from the posterior pharyngeal wall
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Assertion is false but reason is true
 
  • If there is no indication of cervical spine instability, a head-tilt-chin-lift should be done first. The most frequent cause of airway obstruction is posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis.
  • The patient's head is tilted (extended) with pressure from one hand's palm, and the chin is raised with the forefinger and index finger of the other hand.
  • The Jaw-thrust, which is carried out by placing both hands on either side of the patient's head, grabbing the angles of the jaw, and raising, may be more efficient in opening the airway (lifts the tongue from posterior pharyngeal wall).
  • Patient is given “morning air sniffing” position (Chevalier Jackson position) i.e. extension at atlanto-occipital joint and flexion of neck (atlanto axial joint) by keeping a pillow below the neck. This position brings the oral, pharyngeal and laryngeal axis in one line thus facilitating the visualization of vocal cords on direct laryngoscopy



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1393-1396.

questions.text: What does the following ETCO2 curve depicts?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Spontaneous efforts
 
  • In an end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2) graph, spontaneous effort typically appears as irregularities or "dips" in the waveform during mechanical ventilation. This is commonly known as "Curare clefts".
  • These dips occur when the patient attempts to breathe independently, causing a disruption in the smooth pattern of the ventilator's delivered breaths.
  • Spontaneous effort might be reflected on an ETCO2 graph:

    1. Dip in the Plateau Phase: Normally, the ETCO2 waveform has a plateau phase after the peak, which represents the alveolar plateau. Spontaneous effort may cause a sudden dip during this phase, indicating the patient’s attempt to inhale against the ventilator.

    2. Inconsistent Waveform: The otherwise regular and consistent waveform might show variability in amplitude or frequency due to the patient's spontaneous breathing efforts.

    3. Increased Frequency: If the patient is making multiple spontaneous efforts, you may see a more frequent waveform pattern, potentially with smaller breaths between the regular ventilator-delivered breaths




Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no: 1311.

  • Able to deliver 60 to 70 L/min of 95-100% FiO2. 
  • Can produce PEEP between 4 and 6 mm Hg if the patient keeps the mouth close.

questions.text: A 30 year old man had surgery while being intubated. The most effective way to verify the location of the endotracheal tube is:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. ETCO2

  • The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement. If doubt remains, then flexible bronchoscopy, although not routinely used, is very reliable at confirming ETT placement.
  • In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography)

Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
  1. Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  2. Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  3. Symmetric chest rise
  4. Absence of epigastric breath sound
  5. Visible mist in the ET tube
  6. Large exhaled Tidal volume
  7. Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

  • The chin lift is a simple and effective method to relieve airway obstruction in patients who do not have a suspected cervical spine injury

questions.text: What causes EEG slowing during anaesthesia induction?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Hypothermia
 
  • EEG slowing/suppression during induction of anesthesia is due to Hypothermia.
  • Profound hypothermia leads to completely electrically silent EEG. 
  •  During anesthesia induction, the brain's activity slows down, which is reflected in the EEG as a decrease in frequency and amplitude. This slowing of EEG activity is a normal response to anesthesia and is caused by the action of anesthetics on the brain.
  • Hypothermia, or a decrease in body temperature, is a common side effect of anesthesia. It can occur due to a number of factors, including exposure to cold operating room temperatures, administration of cold intravenous fluids, and decreased metabolic rate.
  • Hypothermia can lead to a decrease in brain activity, which is reflected in the EEG as slowing of the frequency and amplitude.
  • Ketamine and nitrous oxide are also commonly used anesthetics, but they do not typically cause EEG slowing during induction. Early hypoxia, or a decrease in oxygen supply to the brain, can cause EEG changes, but it is not a common cause of EEG slowing during anesthesia induction.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1275.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Xenon in anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Slow induction and slow recovery
 
  • Xenon  is inert, non-explosive, environment friendly having low blood solubility with minimal cardiovascular side effects.
  • Xenon is one of the most ideal anesthetic agent but as it's rare element it's not used much for anesthesia. 
  • Xenon has favorable pharmacodynamic effects in comparison to most inhaled anesthetics. It produces minimal cardiovascular depression and is not arrhythmogenic.
  • Lower blood gas coefficient of Xenon results in rapid induction and recovery.
  • Its solubility in blood (λb/g = 0.14) and body tissues is lower than that of any other inhaled anesthetic, including N2O. As a result, it has extraordinarily rapid onset and respiratory clearance, with emergence times 2 to 3-fold faster when it replaces N2O in clinical settings.
  • It is seldom used in clinical practice because of high cost.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 537, 566-568.

Correct option: 1. Depth of general anesthesia

EEG in anesthesia is useful in:

questions.text: A 4-year-old was intubated while being prepared for a craniotomy. Anesthesia equipment suddenly began to display bellows. What is the subsequent course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Start manual ventilation
Next management is to start manual ventilation with Bag and Mask, as this allows for immediate control of the patient's oxygenation and ensures patient safety during the surgery.
 
  • This condition in question is known as collapse of bellows.
  • Collapse of Bellows generally means there is a leak in the circuit, and basically that the tidal volume will not get delivered and the patient is not ventilated.
  • Next step would be quick assessment of any disconnections in the circuit and ruling out other causes of leak in the circuit while simultaneously ventilating manually till the cause of collapse of bellows is found.
  • Increasing flow rate or using a bigger tube in case of leak is not appropriate step.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2359.

questions.text: A newborn in need of intubation had respiratory distress. What is the quickest and most reliable way to verify intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Capnography
 
  • The fastest and most accurate method to confirm intubation is capnography.
  • Capnography is the monitoring of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the respiratory gases and it is known to be the surest confirmatory sign of correct intubation.
  • The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement. If doubt remains, then flexible bronchoscopy, although not routinely used, is very reliable at confirming ETT placement.
  • In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography)

Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:
  • Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Absence of epigastric breath sound
  • Visible mist in the ET tube
  • Large exhaled Tidal volume
  • Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

questions.text: Only the soft palate is visible while evaluating a patient's mouth openness prior to surgery. What is mallampati grade for the test?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. III
 
  • The Mallampati classification system is used to assess the difficulty of intubation by evaluating the visibility of specific structures in the oral cavity.
  • Grade III is assigned when only the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible.
  • This grade suggests potential difficulty in intubation due to a reduced view of the laryngeal structures and limited access to the trachea.
  • A higher Mallampati grade indicates a more difficult intubation, with Grade 1 being the easiest and Grade 4 being the most challenging.





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1379.

choices.text: Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are 940 nm and 660 nm

questions.text: Select the statement that is incorrect regarding pulse oximetry:
questions.solution:
Heart rate can be measured with pulse oximeter.
  • Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive method of measuring the oxygen saturation (SpO2) in arterial blood.
  • It measures the absorption of light by hemoglobin in the blood, which varies depending on whether the hemoglobin is carrying oxygen or not.
  • The pulse oximeter uses two wavelengths of light, typically 660 nm and 940 nm, to measure the oxygen saturation.
  • The ratio of the absorption of these two wavelengths is used to calculate the SpO2.
  • Isosbestic points of oxygenated and reduced hemoglobin are  940 nm and 660 nm as mentioned in option 2.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because pulse oximetry can also measure heart rate by detecting changes in blood volume during each pulse. 


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1301, 1302.

choices.text: Muscle relaxant and induction agent is given simultaneously
Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients
Tubes with low pressure and high-volume cuffs are used

questions.text: Not true about Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI) is:
questions.solution:
RSI is a technique primarily used for emergency airway management in patients who are conscious or semiconscious with a risk of aspiration. It is not suitable for patients in cardiac arrest, as sedation and muscle relaxation are unnecessary in that scenario.
 

  • Pre-oxygenation with 100% O2 for 3 minutes: (Option 1)

    • True. Pre-oxygenation is a standard part of rapid sequence intubation (RSI) to increase oxygen reserves and reduce the risk of hypoxia during apnea.
 

  • Muscle relaxant and induction agent is given simultaneously: (Option 2)

    • True. In RSI, an induction agent (e.g., propofol, etomidate) and a rapid-onset muscle relaxant (e.g., succinylcholine, rocuronium) are given back-to-back without bag-mask ventilation to minimize aspiration risk.
 

  • Method of choice for cardiac arrest patients: (Option 3)

    • False. RSI is not typically used in cardiac arrest because patients are already unresponsive and do not require sedatives or muscle relaxants. Instead, direct intubation or other airway management techniques are used.
 

  • Tubes with low pressure and high-volume cuffs are used: (Option 4)

    • True. Endotracheal tubes with low-pressure, high-volume cuffs are preferred to ensure a proper seal, reduce the risk of aspiration, and minimize tracheal damage.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1382.

questions.text:
Q3. This given device is used for all of the following except

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Following are the functions of tracheostomy tube:
  • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction - thus useful in upper airway obstruction. (option C)
  • ﻿﻿﻿Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance. It allows positive pressure ventilation.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Allows administration of anesthesia.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page. No - 1392.

choices.text: The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of intubation for this patient?

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of intubation for this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with severe maxillofacial trauma, especially after a road traffic accident, airway compromise is common due to:

  • Facial swelling

  • Bleeding

  • Fractures of the mandible or midface

  • Obstruction of oral and nasal passages

Key points:

  • Orotracheal or nasotracheal intubation may be impossible or unsafe in such cases because of obstructed airway or risk of worsening facial injuries.

  • Emergency tracheostomy (or cricothyrotomy in extreme emergencies) provides a definitive airway bypassing the upper airway obstruction.

  • LMA and mask ventilation are temporizing measures but may not be effective if the airway is blocked.

questions.text: Among the following, identify the second generation, LMA
questions.solution:
(i) Intubating laryngeal mask airway

(ii) Flexible laryngeal mask airway

(iii) LMA fastrach

(iv) Proseal LMA

  • Proseal LMA is a 2nd generation LMA device as it has a separate gastric tube to decompress the stomach and prevent gastric aspiration associated with the classical LMA or 1st generation LMA.
  • Other 2nd generation LMA's include LMA Supreme, I-Gel and LMA Protector.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 586.

questions.text: A 70 kg patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted to the ICU and intubated. The current ventilatory settings are: FiO2 90%, PEEP 12 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. The ABG analysis results are as follows:pH: 7.33, PaO2: 110 mmHg, PaCO2: 58 mmHg, SpO2: 100%. What should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Given the ABG and ventilatory settings, the patient has a mild respiratory acidosis (pH 7.33, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg), but their oxygenation (PaO₂ 110 mmHg, SpO₂ 100%) is adequate, especially considering the high FiO₂ (90%). Prolonged exposure to such a high FiO₂ can lead to oxygen toxicity, so reducing FiO₂ is the safest initial step if oxygenation remains stable.

Recommended next step: 3. Reduce FiO₂

Reducing FiO₂ gradually to the lowest level that maintains adequate oxygenation (SpO₂ > 88%) is advisable. This can help reduce potential oxygen toxicity while maintaining adequate oxygenation.

 

  • The primary treatment approach shown to reduce mortality in patients with ARDS is low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Increasing the tidal volume (option 1) in this patient could lead to barotrauma, as increased airflow can damage already collapsed alveoli.
 
  • Although high PEEP helps keep alveoli open, there’s no need to increase PEEP further (option 2) in this case, as oxygenation is already adequate. PEEP should be optimized to allow for the lowest FiO₂ necessary to maintain adequate PaO₂.
 
  • Hypercapnia is expected in low tidal volume ventilation and can be managed by increasing the respiratory rate. Patients typically tolerate respiratory acidosis up to a pH of 7.2—known as permissive hypercapnia. Reducing the respiratory rate (option 4) would increase PaCO₂ and worsen respiratory acidosis.
 
  • Other approaches, like prone positioning, early neuromuscular blockade (to prevent ventilator dys-synchrony), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), have also shown mortality benefits in ARDS. In contrast, interventions like glucocorticoids and surfactant replacement have not been shown to improve outcomes in ARDS.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2227-2229, 2233.

questions.text: An ICU patient who was already on endotracheal intubation now requires a tracheostomy. Which type of tube will you use?
questions.solution:
A cuffed tracheostomy tube is being utilized for this patient's tracheostomy.


 
  • Cuffed tracheostomy tubes are typically preferred for unconscious patients or those requiring prolonged ventilation.
  • When the cuff is inflated, it not only helps prevent the aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea but also reduces air leakage.
  • It is essential to deflate the cuff every two hours for five minutes to avoid pressure necrosis of the tracheal cartilage.
  • Metallic tubes (Option 4) and uncuffed tracheostomy tubes (Option 1) are less commonly used due to their associated risks, including potential displacement and aspiration of secretions into the trachea.



Reference: P.L Dhingra's Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head & Neck Surgery, 8th edition, Page no 563, 564.

choices.text: 25 to 0.60 irrespective of the patient's breathing effort?

questions.text: Which of the following airway devices helps in maintaining FiO2 of 0.25 to 0.60 irrespective of the patient's breathing effort?
questions.solution:
Venturi Mask and Oxygen Delivery
The Venturi mask is effective in maintaining a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) between 0.25 and 0.60, regardless of the patient's breathing efforts.


Classification of Oxygen Delivery Devices
Oxygen delivery devices can be categorized into two main groups:

Low-Flow Oxygen Devices:
Examples include nasal cannula, simple face mask, and non-rebreathing mask.
High-Flow Oxygen Devices:
The Venturi mask falls into this category, providing a fixed-performance oxygen delivery system.
The Venturi mask can deliver a maximum oxygen concentration of 60% FiO2 at a flow rate of 15 L/min. This device is particularly beneficial for patients requiring higher FiO2 levels, such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), where controlled oxygenation is crucial. The masks are available in various colors, with the green valve specifically delivering 60% FiO2.

questions.text: Resistance of the tube shown below is primarily because of:
questions.solution:
The airway device depicted in the image is an endotracheal tube (ETT), and the resistance to airflow through it is primarily influenced by its internal diameter.

The size of an endotracheal tube typically refers to the internal diameter measured in millimeters (mm). Occasionally, the French scale is utilized, where the size corresponds to the external diameter multiplied by three.

For adult patients, a 7-mm tube is commonly used for women, while men typically use a 7.5 mm or 8-mm ETT.

Generally, high-volume, low-pressure cuffed tubes are preferred for adults, whereas cuffless tubes are more suitable for neonates and infants.

In addition to the patient's age, the selection of an endotracheal tube is influenced by any existing airway pathologies and the underlying reason for intubation.

Smaller-sized tubes result in increased airway resistance and higher work of breathing.

Conversely, larger tubes carry a greater risk of laryngeal and tracheal trauma, as well as a higher likelihood of sore throat.

choices.text: It can cause damage to the teeth
It can be used in conscious patients
It can be safely used in facial trauma cases

questions.text: An anesthetist used the airway device shown in the image given below on a patient. Which among the following statements is true regarding the adjunct?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a nasopharyngeal airway and its insertion. The true statement is that it can be used in conscious patients.
  • A nasopharyngeal airway is used to provide artificial airway passage to the hypopharynx. To place a nasopharyngeal airway, the device should be lubricated and inserted into the nose with the bevel facing the nasal septum, at a 90-degree angle to the longitudinal axis of the body. It bypasses the gag reflex as they do not go through the mouth.
  • Thus, it can be used in conscious patients or those who have been lightly anesthetized.
Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 1388.

questions.text: Which is the ideal position for Ryle’s tube insertion?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Sitting with neck flexed
 
  • If the patient is conscious, the best position for inserting the Ryle's tube is sitting with the neck flexed at 45 degrees angle and patient is asked to take sips of water by straw. 
  • The best position for comatose individuals is supine with the neck flexed. 

The steps for inserting a Ryles tube include: 
  • Position: A conscious patient should be Sitting with neck flexed.
  • Check placement: Ask the patient to speak to assess the tube's position. You can also use pH paper to measure the aspirate pH. 
  • Secure: Tape the tube to the patient's cheek to hold it in place. 
  • Preparation: Put on gloves, gown, and face shield. Check the nostrils for obstructions and patency. Place a towel over the patient's chest. 
  • Anesthesia: Spray a topical anesthetic in the nostril and pharynx at least five minutes before insertion. 
  • Lubricate: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the tip of the tube. 
  • Insert: Gently insert the tube into the nose, aiming toward the earlobe. 
  • Advance: Ask the patient to take sips of water through a straw while advancing the tube. 
It's important to verify the tube's placement before each feeding to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia. 

Confirmation of correct position of Ryles tube:
  1. Auscultation of epigastrium while injecting bolus of air through it
  2. Chest radiography
  3. pH measurement
  4. Ultrasound


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 336.

questions.text: Which of the following assertions about the distinction between adult and kid resuscitation is correct?
questions.solution:
Ventricular dysrhythmias are uncommon in children is the CORRECT statement
 
  • Ventricular dysrhythmias are not a common cause of cardiac arrest in children and it is more commonly caused due to hypoxia induced Bradycardia.
  • This is why rescue breaths are important in the case of pediatric resuscitation. Most cardiac arrests in pediatric cases are caused by respiratory failures which is why ventilation is given importance during resuscitation procedure. Ventilation is same as adults (30:2)
  • Infant myocardium more refractory to hypoxia because of Higher glycolytic activity, increased myocardial reserve and higher levels of HbF

questions.text: Which of the following is the best clinical guide for the management of resuscitation from shock?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Urine output
 
  • Best guide for the management of resuscitation is urine output.
  • It is assumed that patients who respond well to fluid infusion (normalisation of vital signs, clearing of the sensorium, and warm fingers and toes with normal capillary refill) also have acceptable general perfusion. A quantitative, accurate sign of organ fusion is urine output.
  • In an adult, a child, and a newborn under 1 year old, an adequate urine output is 0.5 mL/kg per hour, 1 mL/kg per hour, and 2 mL/kg per hour, respectively.
  • CVP (central venous pressure), is a measure of the pressure in the large veins near the heart. While it can be a useful indicator of fluid status in patients, it is not always a reliable guide for resuscitation management.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 18, 19, 671.

questions.text: Which of the following sequences is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Assess the patient’s response, call for help, Check carotid pulse, start CPR

According to the Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) algorithm, steps followed are:
  • Assess the patient's response,
  • Call for help,
  • Check carotid pulse,
  • Start CPR.




Reference: Adult BLS Algorithm for Healthcare Providers, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2262.

questions.text: An unresponsive patient has been brought to you by the police. What will you do initially, precisely?
questions.solution:
Since the patient in the question is already identified as being unresponsive, we should go on to the next BLS phase, which is Checking for Pulse.

Steps of BLS:

  • Airway
  • Breathing
  • Send for AED
  • Circulation
  • Give rescue breaths 
  • Continue CPR





Reference: Adult BLS Algorithm for Healthcare Providers, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2262.

choices.text: Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: You are presented with a 45-year-old patient who is experiencing persistent, severe haemorrhage. The patient's hemodynamics are stable and they are awake. What will the first management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
 
  • Any patient who has collapsed or likely to collapse should have their airway managed first as part of the ATLS strategy.
  • The airway is the most crucial system at risk in this patient and needs prompt care because the patient's hemodynamics are stable.
  • To reduce the danger of aspiration of blood, the patient should be placed in a recovery posture, or left lateral decubitus.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 391, 392.

questions.text: What is the ratio of breaths to chest compressions when performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation alone in an adult?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. 30:2

Whether there are one or two rescuers, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breath for all persons is 30:2, i.e. 30 chest compressions for 2 breathing pauses, if no advanced airway is placed.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2261.
Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: What are the most frequent artefacts of rib fractures during resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 3rd - 5th ribs
 
  • Studies have generally shown that rib fractures resulting from conventional CPR are quite common, with the left side being more fractured than the right.
  • The majority of rib fractures (65%-70%) occur at the 3rd-6th ribs, and the majority of sternal fractures (1.3-43.3%) occur in the middle or lower third of the sternum.
  • Most patients present with multiple anterior rib fractures with ribs no. 3-6 on the left side get injured most commonly during CPR, esp. rib no 3,4 and 5. [Controversial question]
  • Answer depends on the Answer key used {However, 3–5 ribs better answer than 4–6th ribs}.





Reference: Deliliga, Aspasia et al. “Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) complications encountered in forensic autopsy cases.” BMC emergency medicine vol. 19,1 23. 28 Feb. 2019, doi:10.1186/s12873-019-0234-5.
Jaeger, Deborah et al. “Left rib fractures during cardiopulmonary resuscitation are associated with hemodynamic variations in a pig model of cardiac arrest.” Resuscitation plus vol. 15 100429. 14 Jul. 2023, doi:10.1016/j.resplu.2023.100429

questions.text: After taking NSAIDS for a headache, a woman experienced dyspnea, pruritus, and urticaria one hour later. Examining the chest revealed rales with a blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg. Except for _________, all of the following can be utilised for initial management.
questions.solution:
Colloid infusion has no/limited role in the management of Anaphylactic shock. Colloids are used in case of resuscitation of burns after first day. 
 
  • NSAID-induced hypersensitivity reactions can cause anaphylaxis, which presents with various symptoms such as difficulty breathing, skin manifestations, and hypotension. .
  • The initial management of anaphylaxis includes: Crystalloids infusion: to maintain blood volume and counteract hypotension. Early respiratory support and oxygenation: This is crucial to ensure adequate oxygen supply and relieve respiratory distress.
  • Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is the first-line treatment for anaphylaxis. It acts rapidly to reverse bronchoconstriction, increase blood pressure, and relieve symptoms.
  • Dose of adrenaline- 0.5mg IM 1:1000 dilution.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 516.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in CPCR, according to "AHA 2023 Guidelines"?
questions.solution:
• According to the "AHA 2023 Guidelines", atropine is not recommended for use in cardiac arrest as a routine medication during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).
  • Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that can increase heart rate and is used to treat certain types of bradyarrhythmias protocol
  • Recent studies have shown that it does not improve outcomes in cardiac arrest and may even be harmful in some cases. Therefore, the AHA no longer recommends the routine use of atropine during CPR.
  • Instead, the focus is on high-quality chest compressions, early defibrillation, and appropriate medications such as adrenaline and amiodarone.




Reference: Adult algorithm cardiac arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 
Turkish out-of-hospital cardiac arrest study: TROHCA, Turkish Journal of Emergency Medicine, 24, 3, (133-144), (2024).https://doi.org/10.4103/tjem.tjem_73_24

questions.text: A woman is posted for elective cholecystectomy. Her preoperative clinical evaluation and airways assessment was normal. In the operating room, she was attached to the monitors and an antibiotic was administered to her. Suddenly she became pulseless and unresponsive. What should be the next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Start chest compression
 
  • A patient, who suddenly becomes pulseless and unresponsive during giving drugs, in that start chest compression first because Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is the most effective way to keep oxygen-rich blood flowing throughout the body.
  • Starting chest compressions will pump blood to vital organs and keep them functioning until the patient can be revived.
  • Chest compressions will reduce the chances of brain damage or death due to lack of oxygen if the patient is not breathing and has no pulse.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2261.
Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

choices.text: IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is experiencing respiratory distress, nausea, vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain. His pulse rate was 115/min and his blood pressure was 90/60 mm Hg. The ER took the chest X-ray that is shown below. Which is the next best course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

The given chest X-Ray shows gas under diaphragm suggestive of Hollow viscus perforation.
  • The immediate management in place should be IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy.
 
  • The immediate management should focus on stabilizing the patient's vital signs and treating the underlying infection. IV fluids and antibiotics can help to stabilize the patient's blood pressure and address the infection, till then the patient can be prepared for Laparotomy.
 
  • Emergency Laparotomy is necessary to identify and repair the site of perforation to prevent further complications and is the definite line of management.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 413, 414.

questions.text: Which of the following coloured intravenous cannulas will you insert in a dehydrated patient for quick fluid resuscitation?
questions.solution:
For a quick fluid resuscitation, widest bore cannula available should be used for cannulation. Among the cannulas mentioned here, grey has the largest bore, i.e. 16 G.

questions.text:
What constitutes effective CPR?
A. RR : 20 - 24/min
B. Chest compression : 100 - 120/min
C. Allow chest recoil
D. 5-6 cm compression
questions.solution:
High-quality CPR performance include:

  • Chest compression fraction >80%
  • Compression rate of 100-120/min, push hard and fast.
  • Allowing proper recoil time for the chest
  • Compression depth of at least 50 mm (2 inches) in adults and at least 1/3 the AP dimension of the chest in infants and children
  • 30:2 compression:ventilation ratio
  • No excessive ventilation




Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 3201.
Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

choices.text: Check aortic pulse - Start CPR - Call for help - Defibrillate
Call for help - Check for Pulse - Start CPR - Defibrillate if there is no pulse
Observe the patient and wait till the ambulance arrives

questions.text: You came across the unconscious man on the road during your evening stroll through the park. Which of the following options represents the ideal course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Call for help - Check for Pulse - Start CPR - Defibrillate if there is no pulse

According to BLS:
The correct sequence is
  1. Verify scene safety
  2. If victim is unresponsive, call for help
  3. Look for breathing and pulse
  4. Start CPR
  5. Defibrillate in case pulse is absent


Reference: Adult BLS Algorithm for Healthcare Providers, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: Where does damage control resuscitation's second stage take place?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of damage control surgery involves correction of deadly triad of trauma- hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis in the intensive care unit (ICU).
  • The concept of damage control surgery (DCS) was developed because severely traumatised patients with impaired physiology have poor outcomes after lengthy and complex surgical reconstructive procedures performed shortly after their trauma.
  • Prolonged procedures result in additional trauma and further immune and physiological derangement; the ‘triad of death’ – a cycle of acidosis, coagulopathy and hypothermia – may develop and result in multiorgan failure and death.


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 351, 358.

questions.text: Which is an exception to mandatory steps of Traditional Rapid Sequence induction?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. IV adrenaline
 
  • Traditional Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) is a technique used to rapidly induce anesthesia while minimizing the risk of aspiration of gastric contents like pregnancy, obstruction. 
  • Order: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen -> Administer IV induction agent -> IV succinylcholine -> Do not ventilate -> Direct laryngoscopy and intubation -> Confirm endotracheal tube placement -> Remove cricoid pressure.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1382, 1383.

questions.text:
A patient was found lying unconscious. Choose the correct sequence of management? 
(a) Chest compression 
(b) Bap and Mask ventilation 
(c) Check Pulse 
(d) Check Response 
Choose the correct sequence:
questions.solution:
This sequence is based on the basic life support (BLS) guidelines recommended by the American Heart Association (AHA) and other organizations.
  • The first step is to check the response of the patient, followed by checking for pulse.
  • If there is no response or pulse, then the next step is to perform chest compression to maintain circulation.
  • Once the circulation is established, the next step is to provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing. 





Reference: Adult Basic Life Support Algorithm, AHA 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text:
Q1. Patient is kept in the following position when:

1. Patient is unresponsive, not breathing, no pulse
2. Patient is unresponsive, with pulse and breathing present
3. Patient is unresponsive, not breathing but pulse is present
4. Patient is unresponsive, breathing but pulse is absent
questions.solution:
This position is called the recovery or the semi-prone position which is used for patients who are unconscious but still breathing.
The recovery position is a useful position when airway is the primary concern, and will not address the circulatory compromise. 

  • The patient who is unable to breath is experiencing respiratory arrest : Rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to support the patient's breathing.
  • It is not physiologically plausible for a breathing patient to have absence of a pulse, as the absence of a pulse implies a lack of circulation, and breathing cannot be present without circulation.
Reference; Douma MJ, Handley AJ, MacKenzie E, Raitt J, Orkin A, Berry D, Bendall J, O'Dochartaigh D, Picard C, Carlson JN, Djärv T, Zideman DA, Singletary EM. The recovery position for maintenance of adequate ventilation and the prevention of cardiac arrest: A systematic review. Resusc Plus. 2022 Apr 29;10:100236. doi: 10.1016/j.resplu.2022.100236. PMID: 35515010; PMCID: PMC9065878.

questions.text:
Q2. Which maneuver is being performed?

1. Jaw thrust
2. Head tilt, chin lift
3. In-line spine stabilization
4. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation
questions.solution:
The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift.

  • It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page No 2157.

questions.text:
Q4. Identify the procedure shown below:
